transcripts.text: Welcome back.  Thanks again to the great Michael Moore.  It's time for the salt, Anna.  What do we got?

Well, let me just preface this by saying that Michael and I really bonded over our mutual amusement regarding Dave Rubin.  So Dave Rubin, someone I actually used to work with, someone who I actually used to be close with, apparently had some sort of political awakening.  At least that's the way he describes it.  where all of a sudden he doesn't believe in anything he used to believe and likes to rub shoulders with all sorts of right-wingers.  So he's coming out with a new book and he's promoting it on various shows, including on Adam Carolla's program.  And in a recent interview, Dave Rubin decided to specifically go after Bernie Sanders, progressive members of Congress, and question their intelligence and literacy when it comes to the economy.  Let's take a quick look.

the left there is no unifying principle anymore.  what there is is oh i really believe in government and then the next guy just has to outdo you with government.  so it's like bernie comes in and says i believe in 15 minimum wage and it's like bernie's never run a business.  he has no idea about economics or anything but he picks an arbitrary number because he feels it's morally right.  and then what happens literally a week later?  well rashida talib from the squad, you know, one of these new Congresswomen, she says $20 minimum wage.  And it's like, well, I guess, you know, Bernie just made up a number, so now she made up a number and her number's higher, so she must be more moral.  And that sort of race to outdo each other, to pretend that you know what you're doing, in the name of doing good, well, it leads to all sorts of horrific policies and all sorts of stuff.  I mean, when they say they're for free college, well, first off, we know nothing is free.  But even putting that aside, even putting that aside, if you wanted to indoctrinate people into being progressive, socialist, collectivist, leftist, where would you send them?  You'd send them all to college.
I mean... Oh my god, that's awesome.

The lack of self-awareness is my favorite thing about Dave Rubin.  And I want you all to think of this particular line from the last video you just watched.  He accused Bernie Sanders of pretending to know what you're doing.  Pretending to know what you're doing.  Now, we all know Rubin is a grifter.  When he pivoted toward right wing politics, he had some pretty significant financial backers.  Koch brothers were involved.  Dennis Prager was involved.  And like, you know, they were buttering his bread and he decided like this is where the money is.  I'm going to go ahead and start spouting right wing talking points.  But you do have to do some legwork in politics.  being a grifter.  You need to study the talking points.  You need to know or at least expect what the counter argument is.  And you need to be at least somewhat savvy.  And there are grifters on the right who do a decent job at this.  They're a little more sophisticated.  Dave Rubin's not one of those people.  And so while he just accused Bernie Sanders and Rashida Tlaib of pretending to know what they're doing, keep that in mind as you watch this clip.

The government doesn't do anything good.  Name one problem you could possibly have in your life, Joe Rogan, that you'd be like, let me get the government to solve this.  Do they do the post office well?  No.  What do they do well?  They do the post office pretty good, actually.  But guess what?  If the post office closed tomorrow, it would be all right.  You'd still get mail.  It would suck.  Amazon would pick that up.  You'd have to send things through UPS.  It would cost a lot more.  It wouldn't, though.  Competition would start kicking in.  And between UPS and FedEx and Amazon and drones and blah, blah, blah, and DHL, they'd all start, it would probably drop prices because right now we've just got this artificial thing that sits there that then allows them to price according to that.  But if you drop that, why is the government in that business anymore?
No, I just, I love all of it.  I love all of it.  Competition will start kicking in.  That was one of my favorite Rogan interviews ever.

I also just love – I mean Rogan did a great job there with just like his patience.  But like just the fact that Amazon runs off of the – like you cannot have Amazon without the post office.  It's great.  Beautiful.  No, it's just so good.  I mean obviously it's just a question of what you do.  is you just set – you just say I want government to do more things and that's moral. I want them to do things.  And we were like, thank you.
